bibl.title: Abstract: Etiology of Yellow Fever, by J.A.G. Froes, 1924

div1.p: Froes's article concerns the etiology of yellow fever.

div1.head: Abstract: Etiology of Yellow Fever, by J.A.G. Froes, 1924
div1.opener:
Froes, J.A.G.: (Etiology of Yellow Fever), Brazil Medico, 38:245, 1924.XXXVIII
No. 18. p. 245.
div1.p:
The author points out the perfect analogy between human
yellow fever and an experimental infection with the leptospira.
The causative agent must exist in the blood of patients in
relatively small numbers, judging from the quantity required
for the production of the disease in man. The small proportion
of leptospiras in the blood accounts for the difficulty of
their demonstration. Not all the insects which such yellow
fever blood becomes infected, but only a small percentage.
The Leptospira icteroides exists in small quantity in the
blood of infected laboratory animals, and its presence is
rarely demonstrable by the microscope. Of the mosquitoes
sucking the blood of these animals only a small percentage
became infected. A positive blood culture, from man or
laboratory animals, will yield in either case a small number
of satisfactory results. It is not reasonable to exclude the
possible persistence of the yellow fever virus in the blood
after three days of the disease, as a sufficient number of
experiments have never been made. In the organism of the
insects, the virus may persist for several months.
